items.title: Update Conda noarch to 2.0.0
items.body:
Hi all,

I have been having trouble upgrading omegaconf on Conda. The architecture specific versions have all be upgraded on conda-forge to 2.0.0, but the noarch version is still at 1.4.1. However, a bunch of other packages that are in noarch depend on omegaconf and so when I try to upgrade it, it then gets downgraded by the conda system.

Would it be possible to also upgrade the noarch version on conda to match the others?

Thanks!

items.title: Error merging into Optional[List[Any]] = None
items.body:
This is my dataclass and yaml file:

```python
@dataclass
class MultiStepLR:
    _target_: str = "torch.optim.lr_scheduler.MultiStepLR"
    milestones: Optional[List[int]] = None
    gamma: float = MISSING
    last_epoch: int = -1
```

Here's the yaml content of a file called `multi_step.yaml`
```yaml
# @package _group_
milestones:
  - 30
  - 60
  - 80
gamma: 0.1
last_epoch: -1
```

This is the registation with `ConfigStore`:

```
ConfigStore.instance().store(group="lr_scheduler", name="multi_step", node=MultiStepLR)
```

The registration leads to this runtime error
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "hydra/_internal/config_load
er_impl.py", line 610, in _load_config_impl
    merged = OmegaConf.merge(schema.config, ret.config)
  File "omegaconf/omegaconf.py", li
ne 316, in merge
    target.merge_with(*others[1:])
  File "omegaconf/basecontainer.py"
, line 324, in merge_with
    self._format_and_raise(key=None, value=None, cause=e)
  File "omegaconf/base.py", line 10
1, in _format_and_raise
    type_override=type_override,
  File "omegaconf/_utils.py", line
675, in format_and_raise
    _raise(ex, cause)
  File "omegaconf/_utils.py", line
591, in _raise
    raise ex  # set end OC_CAUSE=1 for full backtrace
omegaconf.errors.ValidationError: Invalid value assigned : _GenericAlias is not a subclass of ListConfig or list.
        full_key:
        reference_type=Optional[Dict[Union[str, Enum], Any]]
        object_type=dict

The above exception was the direct cause of the following exception:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "hydra/_internal/utils.py",
line 203, in run_and_report
    return func()
  File "hydra/_internal/utils.py",
line 355, in <lambda>
    overrides=args.overrides,
  File "hydra/_internal/hydra.py",
line 102, in run
    run_mode=RunMode.RUN,
  File "hydra/_internal/hydra.py",
line 512, in compose_config
    from_shell=from_shell,
  File "hydra/_internal/config_loader_impl.py", line 153, in load_configuration
    from_shell=from_shell,
  File "hydra/_internal/config_loader_impl.py", line 256, in _load_configuration
    run_mode=run_mode,
  File "hydra/_internal/config_loader_impl.py", line 797, in _merge_defaults_into_config
    hydra_cfg = merge_defaults_list_into_config(hydra_cfg, user_list)
  File "hydra/_internal/config_loader_impl.py", line 775, in merge_defaults_list_into_config
    package_override=default1.package,
  File "hydra/_internal/config_loader_impl.py", line 690, in _merge_config
    package_override=package_override,
  File "hydra/_internal/config_loader_impl.py", line 622, in _load_config_impl
    ) from e
hydra.errors.ConfigCompositionException: Error merging 'lr_scheduler/multi_step' with schema
```

To reproduce in IPython

```python
from dataclasses import dataclass
from omegaconf import MISSING
from typing import Any, Optional, List
@dataclass
class MultiStepLR:
    target: str = "torch.optim.lr_scheduler.MultiStepLR"
    milestones: Optional[List[int]] = None
    gamma: float = MISSING
    last_epoch: int = -1
from omegaconf import MISSING, OmegaConf
base = OmegaConf.structured(MultiStepLR)
base
yml = OmegaConf.create({"milestones": [1,2,3], "gamma": 0.1, "last_epoch": -1})
res = OmegaConf.merge(base, yml)
```

items.title: Remove dot-keys usage warning and abort compact keys plan.
items.body:
OmegaConf 2.0 started to warn about usage of keys with dot (`a.b.c: 10`) in preparation for compact keys (#152).
Turns out this is causing too many issues and the pressure for compact keys went down significantly:

1. Hydra's packages serves  almost the exact same purpose with a less disruptive change to the yaml semantics.
2.  Hydra itself is already using dot keys for package override, for example:
```yaml
defaults:
 - foo@a.b.c: bar
```

Would place the content of `foo/bar.yaml` in the package a.b.c (`{a:{b:{c: ... }}}`).
This is a dot key that is currently issuing a warning from OmegaConf.

For these reasons, I decided to abandon the idea of compact key support in OmegaConf and I am removing warning on usage of dot keys.

items.title: Merging structured class with a wrong dict doesn't raise an exception.
Runtime error when creating a config from a dataclass using a Set.
items.body:
```python
from omegaconf import OmegaConf
from dataclasses import dataclass
from typing import Set
@dataclass
class Foo:
    s : Set[str]
OmegaConf.structured(Foo(s = {"abc"}))
```

Results in `TypeError: issubclass() arg 1 must be a class`.

1. Set usage error should be specific to set.
2. Unexpected types should be rejected with a proper error and not a runtime error.

items.title: Current yaml loader can't support merge syntax <<
items.body:
When load yaml file with merge syntax `<<`, will have the error: `yaml.constructor.ConstructorError: could not determine a constructor for the tag 'tag:yaml.org,2002:merge' `

```yaml
base: &base
  qqq: cry

General:
  <<: *base
```

This may be caused by the customized loader:
https://github.com/omry/omegaconf/blob/7d5f8fca92119119c3a41c38daddf254d4cf07a5/omegaconf/_utils.py#L84

Possibly related issue:
https://github.com/marcy-terui/lamvery/issues/73#issue-218862548

items.title: Fix interpolation naming discrepancies
items.body:
#308 introduced discrepancies between the intended meaning of some interpolation types vs. the underlying implementation.

For instance, `${foo.${bar}}` is intended to be called a "simple" interpolation, but `get_value_kind()` will identify it as a "string" interpolation. Although the code works fine, this is confusing and could cause other issues down the road => it should be fixed.

The fix may be based on renaming and / or code refactoring (TBD).

items.title: nox session coverage-3.6 fails with python <= 3.6.3
items.body:
Repro steps:

```
conda create -n py363-tmp python=3.6.3 --yes
conda activate py363-tmp
pytest tests/test_base_config.py::TestCopy
```

Observe multiple errors like:
```
FAILED tests/test_base_config.py::TestCopy::test_copy[src0-<lambda>0] - TypeError: __copy__() takes 1 positional argument but 2 were given
```

The error is related to this item in Python 3.6.4 changelog (https://docs.python.org/3.6/whatsnew/changelog.html#python-3-6-4-final):
```
bpo-28556: Two minor fixes for typing module: allow shallow copying instances of generic classes, [...]
```

I ran into this because on my MacBook `nox` is re-using `/opt/homebrew/opt/python36/bin/python3.6` which is 3.6.2.

I couldn't find a way to force `nox` to use Python >= 3.6.4 so I hacked around a PR to just skip these tests when this happens (will submit it shortly).

items.title: Runtime error merging onto structured config field that is set to None
Error when merging MISSING list on top of an existing list
items.body:
Better behavior is to make the target list missing.
```python
In [1]: from omegaconf import ListConfig, OmegaConf
In [2]: l1 = ListConfig([1,2,3])
In [3]: l2 = ListConfig("???")
In [4]: OmegaConf.merge(l1, l2) 
...
MissingMandatoryValue: Cannot iterate a missing ListConfig
        full_key: 
        reference_type=Optional[List[Any]]
        object_type=list
```

desired:
```python
In [1]: from omegaconf import ListConfig, OmegaConf
In [2]: l1 = ListConfig([1,2,3])
In [3]: l2 = ListConfig("???")
In [4]: OmegaConf.merge(l1, l2)
Out[4]: '???'  # <- this is a ListConfig, not a string
```

items.title: Bugs in handling of config flags and config merges
items.body:
1. Message in read-only error on merge is is not helpful.
2. merge_with does not copy the flags from the merged node.

items.title: With a List[int] config option (structured config), a single integer is still parsed as an integer
items.body:
This is a copy of https://github.com/facebookresearch/hydra/issues/758 moved to OmegaConf as per @omry 's request.

The following code runs fine while it should raise an error since `fudge` is supposed to be a list of integers, not an integer.

```python
from dataclasses import dataclass, field
from typing import List
from omegaconf import OmegaConf

@dataclass
class Config:
    fudge: List[int] = field(default_factory=lambda: [])

cfg = OmegaConf.structured(Config)

cfg.fudge = 1
```

items.body:
How to reproduce:
`OmegaConf.create(OmegaConf.create("abc: '10e2'").pretty())`

Output:
`abc: 1000.0`

items.title: Merging a MISSING node does not result in a MISSING reuslt
items.body:
```python
from dataclasses import dataclass
from typing import cast

from omegaconf import MISSING, DictConfig, OmegaConf


@dataclass
class DBConfig:
    host: str = "localhost"
    port: int = MISSING
    driver: str = MISSING


@dataclass
class Config:
    # We can now annotate db as DBConfig, which is more
    # helpful than the Any we used before
    db: DBConfig = MISSING

print(OmegaConf.structured(Config))
print(OmegaConf.merge(Config, Config))
```
result:
```python
{'db': '???'}
{'db': {'host': 'localhost', 'port': '???', 'driver': '???'}}
```

items.title: Merging a sublcass Structured Config that adds a field fails
items.body:
```python
from dataclasses import dataclass
from omegaconf import OmegaConf, MISSING

@dataclass
class DBConfig:
    host: str = "localhost"
    port: int = MISSING
    driver: str = MISSING

@dataclass
class PostGreSQLConfig(DBConfig):
    driver: str = "postgresql"
    port: int = 5432
    timeout: int = 10

assert OmegaConf.merge(DBConfig, PostGreSQLConfig) == PostGreSQLConfig
```

Result:
```
omegaconf.errors.ConfigKeyError: Key 'timeout' not in 'DBConfig'
        full_key: timeout
        reference_type=Optional[DBConfig]
        object_type=DBConfig
```

items.title: OmegaConf is changeing the pyyaml SafeLoader
Iterating where key values exist but value is not set
items.body:
Say I have the `config.yaml` file for Hydra:
```yaml
defaults:
  - foo: null
  - bar: default
```
And the `bar/default.yaml` file is
```yaml
bar:
  val1: ${foo}
  val2: 2
```

Then
```python
False == 'val1' in cfg.bar
True == 'val1' in cfg.bar.keys()
```

and if you try
```python
for k, v in cfg.bar.items():
  ...
```
it will raise the `ConfigKeyError`

FYI, this happens when trying to load the parameters into tensorboard.

items.title: Relax OmegaConf.save() to accept Any
items.body:
It should happily accept either a real OmegaConf object or a structured config (something annotated as dataclass).
there should be a runtime check to make sure input is valid.

items.title: Bugs on Optional/Tuple type: TypeError: issubclass() arg1 must be a class
items.body:
Example:

```python
from typing import Optional, Tuple
from dataclasses import dataclass

@dataclass
class A:
    foo: Optional[Tuple[int]] = None
    bar: Tuple[int] = (1, 2, 3)

from omegaconf import OmegaConf
OmegaConf.structured(A)
```

Stacktrace:
```
.../lib/python3.7/site-packages/omegaconf/omegaconf.py in _node_wrap(type_, parent, is_optional, value, key)
    638     elif type_ == Any or type_ is None:
    639         node = AnyNode(value=value, key=key, parent=parent, is_optional=is_optional)
--> 640     elif issubclass(type_, Enum):
    641         node = EnumNode(
    642             enum_type=type_,

TypeError: issubclass() arg 1 must be a class
```

This happens when an argument to a typing type, e.g. `Tuple`.

items.title: OmegaConf.to_container() fails if node has string interpolation and the container is readonly
items.body:
This fails:

```python
    cfg = OmegaConf.create({"a": 10, "b": {"c": "hello_${a}"}})
    OmegaConf.set_readonly(cfg, True)
    assert OmegaConf.to_container(cfg, resolve=True) == {
        "a": 10,
        "b": {"c": "hello_10"},
    }
```

items.title: GNU-style or POSIX-style argument parsing
items.body:
Omegaconf uses `key=value` style CLIs, but it would be great to support a GNU/POSIX-style CLIs., e.g.

```bash
python main.py --foo=bar --a.b.c=test
```

```python
OmegaConf.from_argv(["--foo", "bar", "--a.b.c=test"])
```

which should yield a conf like

```
foo: bar
a:
  b:
    c: test
```

This standard, conventional style should be beneficial because (i) it is compliant with existing styles and conventions of CLI programs, and because (ii) we can benefit from some third-party tools such as highlighting. For example, the command line `--train_dir /log/abc` can be parsed and recognized by some shell [highlighters](https://github.com/zdharma/fast-syntax-highlighting) but `train_dir=/log/abc` is not, which also is arguably somewhat ugly.

items.title: Error merging into a config with a read only node even if not changing that node.
items.body:
This should work:
```python
cfg1 = OmegaConf.create({"foo": {"bar": 10}})
cfg2 = OmegaConf.create({"foo": {}})
OmegaConf.set_readonly(cfg1, True)
cfg1.merge_with(cfg2)
```
and so should this:
```python
cfg1 = OmegaConf.create({"foo": {"bar": 10}})
cfg2 = OmegaConf.create({"xyz": 10})
OmegaConf.set_readonly(cfg1.foo, True)
cfg1.merge_with(cfg2)
```

items.title: OmegaConf.pretty()
items.body:
Provide an alternative OmegaConf.pretty() to cfg.pretty() to enable pretty printing of duck-typed configs.

We can deprecate it in favor of:

```
OmegaConf.to_yaml(cfg, resolve: bool = False, sort_keys: bool = False)
```

```
/usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/omegaconf/dictconfig.py:252: UserWarning: Keys with dot (../../../vilbert/configs/hateful_memes/from_cc.yaml) are deprecated and will have different semantic meaning the next major version of OmegaConf (2.1)
See the compact keys issue for more details: https://github.com/omry/omegaconf/issues/152
````

items.title: Failure to initialize a config with a nested structured config typed as Any.
items.body:
This fails
```python
from omegaconf import OmegaConf
from typing import Any
from dataclasses import dataclass

@dataclass
class Nested:
  ...

@dataclass
class NestedWithAny:
    var: Any = Nested()

cfg = OmegaConf.structured(NestedWithAny)
```
Result:
```
omegaconf.errors.UnsupportedValueType: Value 'Nested' is not a supported primitive type
        full_key: 
        reference_type=None
        object_type=None
```

items.title: [Feature Request/Question] Save Interpolated Value, Select .. where
items.body:
1)  Let's say I have a yaml like this:
> user: ${env:USER}

And, I want to save the config to a file with the interpolated values. 

Loading a file:
> user = OmegaConf.load('user.yaml')

Writing a file (without referencing any attributes)
> OmegaConf.save(user, 'cfg.yaml')

Should write:
> user:  jsmith

Is this possible?

2) Is it possible to select a node/list of nodes with a where clause?

> users:
>   - type: admin
>   .. 
>   - type: guest
 
I was to select from users where type == 'admin'

Thanks,
Vish

items.title: Upgrade PyYAML to 5.1 or newer
Relax save and load APIs to accept IO[Any]
items.body:
Per comment [here](https://github.com/python/typeshed/issues/1229#issuecomment-304932714):

> open(fn, 'rb') will now return IO[bytes] while open(fn, 'r') will return IO[str]

For easier to use API, it's best to change to IO[Any] to accept files opened in either modes.

items.title: [bug] ListConfig doesn't support negative indices in basic list operations
items.body:
```
from omegaconf import OmegaConf
a = OmegaConf.create({"a": [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]})
b = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]
print(b[1:-1]) # Works fine
print(a.a[1:-1]) # Throws error
print(b[None:None:-1]) # Works fine
print(a.a[None:None:-1])  # Throws error
```

items.title: Invalid error message assigning with an invalid inner Dict key.
items.body:

```python
from dataclasses import dataclass, field
from typing import List, Any, Dict

from enum import Enum

class Color(Enum):
    RED = 1
    BLUE = 2
    GREEN = 3

@dataclass
class Dicts:
    d1: Dict[str, Any] = field(default_factory=lambda: {})
    d2: Dict[Color, str] = field(default_factory=lambda: {})

dicts = OmegaConf.structured(Dicts)
dicts.d2["10"] = "foo"
```

```

{"list": [1, 2, 3]}
```

```
{"list": ListConfig(content="???")}
```

items.title: to_container does not convert special containers properly
items.body:
A nested DictConfig or a ListConfig can represent special values like:
1. Interpolation
2. MISSING
3. None.

OmegaConf.to_container does not handle those correctly, for example:
```
from omegaconf import OmegaConf, DictConfig
print(OmegaConf.to_container(OmegaConf.create({"foo" : DictConfig(content=None)})))
print(OmegaConf.to_container(OmegaConf.create({"foo" : DictConfig(content="${bar}")})))
print(OmegaConf.to_container(OmegaConf.create({"foo" : DictConfig(content="???")})))
```

Desired output:
```
{'foo': None}
{'foo': '${bar}'}
{'foo': '???'}
```

items.title: Warn about usage of . in key (preparing for compact keys)
items.body:
1. provide a user warning if string key contains `.`
2. provide a link to an explanation (#155)
3. allow opt out of the warning.

items.title: pop and del should throw in struct mode
items.body: This is a behavior change. DictConfig pop and del should not be permitted in struct mode (and in structured mode) because it's inconsistent with the the expected behavior of classes.

items.title: [Feature Request] pretty() support enum_to_str
items.body:
Right now for a ENUM to be printed `pretty()` to str we have to do 

```python3

OmegaConf.create(
                OmegaConf.to_container(
                                my_cfg, enum_to_str=True
                            )
                        ).pretty()
```

it'd be great if we can do something like 

```python3

my_conf.pretty(enum_to_str=True)

```

items.title: [bug] Env Interpolation doesn't respect paths
items.body:

```py
from omegaconf import OmegaConf
a = OmegaConf.create({"a": {"b": "${env:DATASET_CONFIG,configs/datasets}"}})
print(a.a.b) # prints '${env:DATASET_CONFIG,configs/datasets}'
```

Should print configs/datasets

Version: 2.0.0.rc24

items.title: [bug] .pop isn't behaving as standard dict in struct mode
items.body:
```py
from omegaconf import OmegaConf
c = OmegaConf.create({"a": 1})
OmegaConf.set_struct(c, True)
c.get("b", 1) # Works fine returns 1
c.pop("b", 1) # Throws ConfigAttributeError
```

Expected:

`.pop` should return value 1

Actual:
Throws ConfigAttributeError

Version: 2.0.0.rc24

Used to work in rc16

items.title: More informative OmegaConf.get_ref_type
items.body: try to return Dict[K, V] and List[T] for DictConfig (unstructured) and ListConfig

items.title: [bug] Nested interpolations don't work
items.body:
Nested interpolations only resolve inner level interpolations.

```py
a = OmegaConf.create({"a": "${hello:${default_hello:}}"})
OmegaConf.register_resolver("hello", lambda x: x)
OmegaConf.register_resolver("default_hello", lambda: 1)
print(a.a) # prints ${hello:1}
```

Expected: 1

The major issue this causes is when I want to register a resolver for an environmental variable's default value.

Workaround:
Register an overall resolver and resolve environment value yourself in it.

items.title: [bug] Interpolations don't respect defaults to .get or .select
items.body:
Given that missing interpolation throw KeyError, they should respect the default value provided to `.get` or `.select`. The example below illustrates it:

```py
a = OmegaConf.create({"a": "${env:HELLO}"})
b = OmegaConf.create({"a": "${b.a}"})
a.select("a", 1) # Throws keyerror
b.select("a", 1) # Throws keyerror
a.get("a", 1) # Throws keyerror
b.get("a", 1) # Throws keyerror
```

Expected:

All examples should return 1

Actual:
All throw keyerror.

Version: Latest rc.

items.title: Double crap in error message

```python
# Copyright (c) Facebook, Inc. and its affiliates. All Rights Reserved
from dataclasses import dataclass

import hydra
from hydra.core.config_store import ConfigStore


@dataclass
class MySQLConfig:
    driver: str = "mysql"

# Registering the Config class with the name 'config'

@hydra.main(config_name="config")
def my_app(cfg: MySQLConfig) -> None:
    # The real type of cfg is DictConfig, but we lie a little to get static type checking.
    # If it swims like a duck and quacks like a duck, it's a "duck".
    print(
        f"Connecting to {cfg.drover} at {cfg.host}:{cfg.port},"
        f" user={cfg.user}, password={cfg.password}"
    )


if __name__ == "__main__":
    my_app()

$ python examples/structured_configs_tutorial/1_basic/my_app.py
...
omegaconf.errors.ConfigAttributeError: Key 'drover' not in 'MySQLConfig'
        full_key: drover
        reference_type=Optional[dict]

        object_type=MySQLConfig
```

items.title: AssertionError constructued Structured Config with nested MISSING fields
items.body:
my script ```my_test.py```

```python3
from dataclasses import MISSING, dataclass
from typing import Optional
from omegaconf import OmegaConf

@dataclass
class AConf:
    count: Optional[int] = MISSING

@dataclass
class SimpleConf:
    aconf: AConf = MISSING

def my_app() -> None:
    conf1 = OmegaConf.structured(SimpleConf)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    my_app()

```

run ```python my_test.py```

stack trace:
```bash
(hydra37) jieru-mbp:hydra jieru$ python /Users/jieru/workspace/hydra-fork/hydra/plugins/hydra_ray_launcher/my_test.py
```

```python
from dataclasses import MISSING, dataclass, field
```

items.title: Variables not resolved when accessing through iterator
items.body:
When accessing `ListConfig` through the iterator, the variables are not resolved. A similar issue is #21 regarding DictConfig.

config.yaml:
```
var1: 1
var2: 2
var3:
  - ${var1}
  - ${var2}
```

test.py:
```
import hydra

from omegaconf import DictConfig


@hydra.main('config.yaml')
def main(cfg: DictConfig) -> None:
    print(cfg.var1)
    print(cfg.var2)
    print(cfg.var3)
    print([x for x in cfg.var3])
    print([cfg.var3[i] for i in range(len(cfg.var3))])
    print(next(iter(cfg.var3)))

    return


if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```

Output:
```
$ python test.py
1
2
['${var1}', '${var2}']
['${var1}', '${var2}']
[1, 2]
${var1}
```

Hydra version: facebookresearch/hydra@b9df40a2
Omegaconf version: 4c5be9a

```
~/miniconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/omegaconf/_utils.py in format_and_raise(node, key, value, msg, cause, type_override)

--> 496     raise ex from cause
```

items.title: Merging configs in OmegaConf 2.0.0rc22

labels.name: question
labels.description: Request for help, not a bug or feature request

items.body:
In my model setup and training, I made a configuration example like this (holding values which I always require) (made shorter):

```python
from dataclasses import dataclass

@dataclass
class DefaultConfig:
    N_EPOCHS: int = 50
```

I would then want to extend the config for different use cases for instance, config.yaml is a yaml holding a 'DEBUG: true' key. 

>     default_cfg = OmegaConf.structured(DefaultConfig)
>     cfg = OmegaConf.merge(default_cfg, OmegaConf.load('config.yaml'))

If I do this I would expect that cfg now has merged the default and the config.yaml, but I get this error 

> omegaconf.errors.ConfigKeyError: Error setting DEBUG=True : Key 'DEBUG' not in 'DefaultConfig'
>         full_key: DEBUG
>         reference_type=Optional[DefaultConfig]
>         object_type=DefaultConfig

items.title: Standardize Exception messages
items.body:
There are some common information thas is applicable to most exceptions:

1. what is the node this happened on.
2. what is the key (if relevent)
3. what is the value (if relevant)
4. what is the full path of the key
etc.

1. refactor things such that all exceptions are going through the same formatting function.
2. add tests for exception messages.

items.title: Structured configs : Consider supporting isinstance checks
[bug] OmegaConf.merge should respect interpolations
Assert configuration is a subset of a template configuration
items.body:
It is sometimes useful to make sure that a certain config is a subset of a given template configuration,
e.g. when passing arguments through the command line.

That way you make sure no keys are "getting lost" and the application is misconfigured.
Assuming a template conf:
```yaml
foo:
  bar: True
  bar2: True
```
I would want something like this:
```py
cfg = OmegaConf.create({"foo": {"bar": 100}})
cfg.assert_subset(template)
cfg = OmegaConf.create({"foo": {"bar1": 100, "bar2": 101}})
cfg.assert_subset(template). # Fails on assertion / KeyError
cfg = OmegaConf.create({"foo2": {"bar": 100, "bar2": 101}})
cfg.assert_subset(template). # Fails on assertion / KeyError
```

Another option would be:
```py
OmegaConf.assert_subset(cfg, template)
```

I've implemented a simple recursion that takes care of DictConfig, and if you see this feature as needed I'll be happy to discuss and then PR.

items.title: [Feature Request] Debug mode for merge
items.body:
Sometimes, we need to know what exactly was overridden for debugging purposes and can save a lot of headaches. 

I can think of two possible solutions here:

`OmegaConf.merge(a, b, debug=True)`. This will have to implemented for other functions such as `merge_from_dot_list` as well and is more useful for my usecase.

Otherwise, you can add logging debug statements which I don't think you use anywhere as of now.

Propose to make this into an own method: `OmegaConf.clear_cache(cfg)`

items.title: [bug] hasattr on missing nested attributes should return False

Minimal example to reproduce the bug:
```
import omegaconf
a= omegaconf.OmegaConf.create({"a": {"b": [1, 2], "c": "abc"}})
print(hasattr(a, "d"))
```
prints `True`. OmegaConf version: `2.0.0rc15`

items.title: Fallback when merg config with enviroment variabels
items.body:
A nice feature for merging configs with environment variables and an environment variable is missing it to fallback to next value in merge order.

Take a look at the following example and suppose VALUE_A does not exist.

```
from omegaconf import OmegaConf

yaml = "a: 12"

yaml_env = "a: ${env:VALUE_A}"

config = OmegaConf.create(yaml)
config_env = OmegaConf.create(yaml_env)
configm = OmegaConf.merge(config, config_env)
print(configm.a)
```

You will get the following error: 
`KeyError: "Environment variable 'VALUE_A' not found"`

It would be nice if you get `12 `in this example.

items.title: Set default value when environment variable is missing
items.body:
It would be nice to be able to set a default value in yaml file for
environment variable interpolation when a variable is missing. 

E.g syntax can be `${env:ENVIROMENT_VARIABLE,default_value}`

`a: ${env:VALUE_A,1}`

if `VALUE_A `do not exist give `1`

items.title: utils.instantiate does not allow passing dictionaries as kwargs
items.body:
Thanks for the helpful library!
Filing a bug in the `utils.instantiate` function.

Suppose I have a config group file
```yaml
model:
  class: models.Net
  params:
    some: 0
    values: 1
```

Let's say I want to pass in a dictionary to `models.Net` as follows:
`utils.instantiate(cfg.model, some_config_argument={'test': 'dict'})`

This will throw `KeyError: 'Accessing unknown key in a struct : model.params.test'`

from `params.merge_with(OmegaConf.create(kwargs))` in the instantiate function.

items.title: Enhancement: Compact key support
items.body:
## Compact keys
This will probably come in OmegaConf 2.1 as 2.0 is closed to new features at this time.

Given:
```yaml
hydra:
  sweeper:
    params:
      budget: 100
      num_workers: 10
```

Allow the same config to be represented by:

```yaml
hydra.sweeper.params:
  budget: 100
  num_workers: 10
```
## Compatibility considerations
This changes the semantic meaning of a key with a dot, from a 
```yaml
foo.bar: 10
```
to:
```yaml
foo:
  bar: 10
```

People using `.` in their keys now should be aware of it and ideally stop doing it (in 1.4 or 2.0).
OmegaConf 2.0 will add a deprecation warning that can be disabled by setting the environment variable `OC_DISABLE_DOT_ACCESS_WARNING` to the value "1".

To address this, there will be multiple opt out mechanisms (fully specification tbd).
some ideas:

- [x] Allow keys with dot by escaping the `.` : `foo\.bar`
- [ ] Possibly allow file level opt out via a special header
- [ ] Possibly allow API level opt out when loading the file or when constructing a DictConfig object.

items.title: Hash value for dictconfig is inconsistent between Python 3.7+ and older versions
items.body:
Hi,
Thanks for this wonderful library! Hydra+omegaconf helps me quite a lot.

I found that a hash value for dictconfig is inconsistent in some cases. Is this an expected behaviour or a bug? 

Suppose I have two identical dictionaries with the different insertion order: `d1={"a": 123, "b": 456}` and `d2 = {"b": 456, "a": 123}`. When printing a dictionary, the order of the insertion is preserved in Python 3.7+, meaning that `str(d1) != str(d2)`. In older Python, the order is ignored and the items are automatically sorted, which means that the string is same: `str(d1) == str(d2)`.



Let me create dictconfig instances from them: `dc1 = OmegaConf.create(d1)` and `dc2 = OmegaConf.create(d2)`. As a hash value of dictconfig is computed based on `str()`, `hash(dc1) != hash(dc2)` for Python 3.7+ and `hash(dc1) == hash(dc2)` for older Python.

This results in a different behaviour for Python 3.7+ and older Python in some cases. For example, if I use `dc1` as the key of a dictionary: `a = {dc1: "xxx", dc2: "yyy"}`, two items are kept in Python 3.7, but only one remains in Python 3.5.

I guess either behaviour is ok, but would it be consistent between different versions of Python3.X?

Thanks!

Reference: ["the insertion-order preservation nature of dict objects has been declared to be an official part of the Python language spec."](https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.7.html)

Test code:
```python
from omegaconf import OmegaConf

# Identical dictionaries with the different insertion order
d1 = {"a": 123, "b": 456}
d2 = {"b": 456, "a": 123}

dc1 = OmegaConf.create(d1)
dc2 = OmegaConf.create(d2)

print(str(d1), str(d2))
# Python 3.5: {'b': 456, 'a': 123} {'b': 456, 'a': 123}  <- Sorted
# Python 3.7: {'a': 123, 'b': 456} {'b': 456, 'a': 123}  <- Not sorted

print(hash(dc1), hash(dc2))
# Python 3.5: -7197075476224411740 -7197075476224411740   <- same
# Python 3.7: 9040302285363809012 -3745572629213257466    <- different

a = {dc1: "xxx", dc2: "yyy"}
print(a)
# The result is different. Which is an expected behavior?
# Python 3.5: {{'b': 456, 'a': 123}: 'yyy'}
# Python 3.7: {{'a': 123, 'b': 456}: 'xxx', {'b': 456, 'a': 123}: 'yyy'}
```

items.title: Disable automatic conversion of date strings in from_dotlist
items.body:
### Issue
When instantiating OmegaConf from `from_dotlist`, yaml loader tries to convert date-formatted strings into `date` type, therefore raises error when validating the type of values.

```
 OmegaConf.from_dotlist(["my_date=2019-11-11"])

>>>

.../site-packages/omegaconf/config.py in _prepare_value_to_add(self, key, value)
    448         if not Config.is_primitive_type(value):
    449             full_key = self.get_full_key(key)
--> 450             raise ValueError("key {}: {} is not a primitive type".format(full_key, type(value).__name__))
    451
    452         if self._get_flag('readonly'):

ValueError: key my_date: date is not a primitive type
```
This error also blocks the overriding of configuration values by using cli arguments in hydra.

### Potential workaround
Could be solved by removing implicit timestamp resolvers in default `yaml.SafeLoader`.
(Related stackoverflow: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/34667108/ignore-dates-and-times-while-parsing-yaml)

items.title: throw AttributeError in struct mode
items.body: In struct mode, accessing an invalid attribute through getattr() should result in an AttributeError and not in a KeyError.

items.title: Consider support yaml aliases
items.body:
Some yaml files are organizing as the following, could you please consider to support that ?
Like the followling from the official documentation https://pyyaml.org/wiki/PyYAMLDocumentation

Aliases
Note that PyYAML does not yet support recursive objects.

Using YAML you may represent objects of arbitrary graph-like structures. If you want to refer to the same object from different parts of a document, you need to use anchors and aliases.

Anchors are denoted by the & indicator while aliases are denoted by ``. For instance, the document

left hand: &A
  name: The Bastard Sword of Eowyn
  weight: 30
right hand: *A
expresses the idea of a hero holding a heavy sword in both hands.

PyYAML now fully supports recursive objects. For instance, the document

&A [ *A ]
will produce a list object containing a reference to itself.

items.title: Bug in FloatNode.__eq__
items.body:
```python
from omegaconf.nodes import FloatNode

x = FloatNode()
x == 1
```

raises

```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-163-39f43fc4ed44> in <module>
      2 
      3 x = FloatNode()
----> 4 x == 1

~/work/omegaconf/omegaconf/nodes.py in __eq__(self, other)
    115             other_val = other
    116 
--> 117         return self.val == other_val or (math.isnan(self.val) and math.isnan(other_val))
    118 
    119 

TypeError: must be real number, not NoneType
```

due to the following line:

https://github.com/omry/omegaconf/blob/7f521275c71565b5bb51d736699e3a11d51bd9cf/omegaconf/nodes.py#L88

`math.isnan` accepts `typing.SupportsFloat` but not `NoneType`.

items.title: Drop support for Python 2.7
items.body:
Python 2.7 is reaching end of life in 1/1/2020

1. ~~Provide an error when running OmegaConf 1.5 with Python 2.7, pointing users to pin 1.4 if they wish to use Python 2.7~~
2. ~~Remove 2.7 support from master, update docs, unit tests (Additional advice [here](https://python3statement.org/practicalities/)~~
3. ~~Clean up 2.7 specific and supporting dependencies~~
4. Leverage Python 3.x features: Type annotations, Mypy/Pyre. clean up Python 2.7 support

items.title: Construction of OmegaConf from Structured Configs
items.body:
The associated PR (#86 ) is adding support for initializing OmegaConf from class files and objects.
Details below

1. Config classes and objects (dataclass or attrs classes) can be converted to OmegaConf object.


2. The following value types are supported:
 - with a default value assigned to it.
 - Optional fields (can accept None)
 - assigned omegaconf.MISSING, Equivalent for '???' in the yaml files (Mandatory missing).
   The semantics here is that this value is not yet set. it must be set prior to read access.
 - Interpolation using omegaconf.II() function :
   II("foo") is equivalent to ${foo} in the YAML file.
   Examples:
   - `foo=II("bar")`  : Foo inherits the type and value of bar at runtime.
   - `foo=II("http://${host}:${port}/")`  : foo is always a string. actual value is determined by host and port
   - `foo=II("env:USER")` : foo is evaluated on access, the type and value is determined by the function (env in this case)

Example for bool types (The same is supported for int, str, float and enum):
```python
@dataclass
class BoolConfig:
    with_default: bool = True
    null_default: Optional[bool] = None
    mandatory_missing: bool = MISSING
    interpolation: bool = II("with_default")
```

3. the typing information in them is available and acted on at runtime (composition and command line overrides are at runtime).

4. type annotations can be used to get static type checking.

Currently the following is supported for both dataclasses and attr classes.
Examples below are @dataclasses. attr classes are similar.
```python
@dataclass
class Database:
    name: str = "demo_app_db"
    # A an untyped list. will accept any type that can be represented by OmegaConf
    tables: List = field(default_factory=lambda: ["table1", "table2"])
    port: int = 3306

    # A list of integers, will reject anything that cannot be converted to int at runtime
    admin_ports: List[int] = field(default_factory=lambda: [8080, 1080])

    # A dict of string -> int, will reject any value that cannot be converted to int at runtime
    error_levels: Dict[str, int] = field(
        default_factory=lambda: {"info": 0, "error": 10}
    )

```

This class, and objects of this class can be used to construct an OmegaConf object:
```python
# Create from a class
conf1 = OmegaConf.create(Database)

# Create from an object
conf2 = OmegaConf.create(Database(port=3307))
```

Python type annotation can then be used on the config object to static type checking:
```python
def foo(cfg : Database):
   cfg.port = 10 # passes static type check
   cfg.port = "nope" # fails static type check
```
5. Composition and overrides are often happening at runtime (from files, or command line flags).
To support that, there is also a runtime validation and conversion.
The following will succeed at runtime:
```python
conf.merge_with_dotlist(['port=30']) # success
conf.merge_with_dotlist(['port=nope']) # runtime error
```
6. OmegaConf objects created from Structured configs will be set to struct mode, this means that any access to a field not in the struct will result in a runtime error:

```python
conf.pork = 80 # fail
```

7. Typed containers are validated at runtime:
```python
conf: Database = OmegaConf.create(Database)
conf.admin_ports[0] = 999  # okay
assert conf.admin_ports[0] == 999

conf.admin_ports[0] = "1000"  # also ok!
assert conf.admin_ports[0] == 1000

with pytest.raises(ValidationError):
    conf.admin_ports[0] = "fail"

with pytest.raises(ValidationError):
    conf.error_levels["info"] = "fail"
```
8. Nested Object/Classes are supported, as well as Enums.
```python

class Protocol(Enum):
    HTTP = 0
    HTTPS = 1


@dataclass
class ServerConfig:
    # Nested configs are by value.
    # This will be expanded to default values for Database
    db1: Database = Database()

    # This will be expanded to the values in the created Database instance
    db2: Database = Database(tables=["table3", "table4"])

    host: str = "localhost"
    port: int = 80
    website: str = MISSING
    protocol: Protocol = MISSING
    debug: bool = False
```
9. Enums can be assigned by Enum, by name string or by value (the later should be used at runtime only).

```python
    conf: ServerConfig = OmegaConf.create(ServerConfig(protocol=Protocol.HTTP))
    assert conf.protocol == Protocol.HTTP

    # The HTTPS string is converted to Protocol.HTTPS per the enum name
    conf.protocol = "HTTPS"
    assert conf.protocol == Protocol.HTTPS

    # The value 0 is converted to Protocol.HTTP per the enum value
    conf.protocol = 0
    assert conf.protocol == Protocol.HTTP

    # Enum names are care sensitive
    with pytest.raises(ValidationError):
        conf.protocol = "https"
 
    for value in (True, False, "1", "http", 1.0):
        with pytest.raises(ValidationError):
            conf.protocol = value
```

10. Frozen state is preserved (and is recursive):
```python
    @dataclass(frozen=True)
    class FrozenClass:
        x: int = 10
        list: List = field(default_factory=lambda: [1, 2, 3])

    conf = OmegaConf.create(FrozenClass)
    with pytest.raises(ReadonlyConfigError):
        conf.x = 20

    # Read-only flag is recursive
    with pytest.raises(ReadonlyConfigError):
        conf.list[0] = 20
```

items.title: OmegaConf object doesn't support a .copy method
items.body:
A dict is supposed to have a .copy() method (https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#dict.copy). For an OmegaConf object to be compatible with a dict's API, it should also support the copy() method -

```
>>> from omegaconf import OmegaConf
>>> conf = OmegaConf.create({"a": 2, "b": [1,2,3]})
>>> conf
{'a': 2, 'b': [1, 2, 3]}
>>> conf.copy()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not callable
```
